sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of social event occurring in a community
message_1: In a certain community, 25% of the households have pets and 60% of the households have children. If it is known that 15% of the households have both pets and children, what is the probability that a randomly selected household has pets or children or both?
message_2:
To find the probability that a randomly selected household has pets or children or both, we can use the formula for the probability of the union of two events:

P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ∩ B)

where A represents the event of having pets, B represents the event of having children, and A ∩ B represents the event of having both pets and children.

We are given the following probabilities:
P(A) = 25% (probability of having pets)
P(B) = 60% (probability of having children)
P(A ∩ B) = 15% (probability of having both pets and children)

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ∩ B)
P(A ∪ B) = 25% + 60% - 15%

P(A ∪ B) = 70%

So, the probability that a randomly selected household has pets or children or both is 70%.
